original_data.question: A healthy 19-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of painless “blisters” in his mouth. He reports that he noticed a white film on his tongue and the sides of his mouth 2 days ago while brushing his teeth. The film was easily brushed off. He also complains of a bitter metallic taste in his mouth but otherwise denies pain, burning, dysphagia, or hoarseness. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He is a competitive swimmer and has had 8 sexual partners in the past year. He intermittently uses barrier protection. On exam, he is well-appearing and in no acute distress. His oral examination demonstrates patches of white pseudomembranes that can be wiped away to reveal erythematous mucosa. A medication with which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate in this patient?

model_response:
This patient’s presentation is most consistent with oral thrush, or candidiasis, which is caused by Candida species. Candidiasis is an opportunistic infection that occurs in immunocompromised patients, and it is the most common fungal infection in both HIV-positive and non-HIV-positive persons. Risk factors for candidiasis include recent antibiotic or glucocorticoid use, diabetes mellitus, alcoholism, and immunosuppression. The pseudomembranous form of candidiasis seen in this patient is called thrush. The medication with which this patient should be treated is an azole, which works by inhibiting 14-alpha-demethylase, thereby disrupting the cell membrane permeability of the fungus. Azoles include fluconazole, itraconazole, and ketoconazole. Newer medications, such as caspofungin and micafungin, work by inhibiting beta-glucan synthase. Caspofungin is used in refractory invasive aspergillosis. Newer medications such as terbinafine work by inhibiting squalene epoxidase, which disrupts ergosterol synthesis. Griseofulvin works by inhibiting microtubule formation.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Having no significant health-related issues.
Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.

Care which provides integrated, accessible health care services by clinicians who are accountable for addressing a large majority of personal health care needs, developing a sustained partnership with patients, and practicing in the context of family and community. (JAMA 1995;273(3):192)
Not causing physical or psychological misery, pain or distress.
Visible accumulations of fluid within or beneath the epidermis.
The oval-shaped oral cavity located at the apex of the digestive tract and consisting of two parts: the vestibule and the oral cavity proper.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.

A group distinguished by classification according to physical features. This group, also called Europoid, centers around the Mediterranean Sea but includes other parts of Europe. (from Winick: Dictionary of Anthropology, 1972; American Heritage Dictionary, 2d College ed)

A muscular organ in the mouth that is covered with pink tissue called mucosa, tiny bumps called papillae, and thousands of taste buds. The tongue is anchored to the mouth and is vital for chewing, swallowing, and for speech.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
The act of cleaning teeth with a brush to remove plaque and prevent tooth decay. (From Webster, 3d ed)
One of a set of bone-like structures in the mouth used for biting and chewing.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
Having a sharp, pungent taste.
The oval-shaped oral cavity located at the apex of the digestive tract and consisting of two parts: the vestibule and the oral cavity proper.
A sensation of stinging or heat, not necessarily accompanied by redness or physical signs of irritation.

Difficulty in SWALLOWING which may result from neuromuscular disorder or mechanical obstruction. Dysphagia is classified into two distinct types: oropharyngeal dysphagia due to malfunction of the PHARYNX and UPPER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER; and esophageal dysphagia due to malfunction of the ESOPHAGUS.
An unnaturally deep or rough quality of voice.
Having no significant health-related issues.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
Married or single individuals who share sexual relations.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
A structure or object that impedes free movement.
An appraisal or evaluation of a patient's condition by a clinician that is based on a physical exam, medical history, and the patient's account of symptoms.
A state of physiological or psychological stress that cannot be compensated for by normal adaptive measures.
A systematic evaluation of the tissues and structures in the mouth.
Formation of membrane-like structures consisting of coagulated exudate that is loosely adherent to an inflamed tissue.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
The means by which an effect is obtained.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
